questions.text: The marked structure in the image arises from the development of which of the following embryological components?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure marked in the image corresponds to the deep inguinal ring, a key anatomical feature of the inguinal canal.

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, located just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament. This defect allows the passage of the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females.

questions.text: Damage at which of the marked locations in the image would most likely result in an inability to dorsiflex the foot?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The injury to the common fibular nerve causes failure of dorsiflexion; thus, the marked structure 3, i.e. neck of the fibula, is the right answer.

questions.text: A student experiences jaw locking during a yawn. Spasm of which muscle, attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint, is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral pterygoid muscle is the only muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

It plays a key role in the movement of the TMJ, particularly in opening the mouth and moving the jaw forward (protraction).

Lateral pterygoid:

Attachment: The superior head of the lateral pterygoid inserts into the articular disc and the joint capsule, while the inferior head attaches to the neck of the mandible.

Function: It helps in:

Depressing the mandible (opening the mouth).

Protrusion and lateral movements of the jaw.

Spasmodic contraction: During excessive yawning, prolonged contraction of the lateral pterygoid can pull the articular disc and the mandible forward, potentially leading to jaw locking due to dislocation of the TMJ.

Explanation for other options:

Temporalis (Option B): This muscle primarily elevates and retracts the mandible; it has no attachment to the articular disc.

Medial pterygoid (Option C): Assists in elevation and side-to-side movements of the mandible but is not connected to the articular disc.

Masseter (Option D): A strong elevator of the mandible; also has no attachment to the articular disc.

Reference:

Anatomy, Head and Neck, Mastication Muscles - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: The provided histological image most likely represents which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure of the histological image given is of the kidney showing a glomerulus by proximal convoluted tubules (PCT), and distal convoluted tubules (DCT).

Glomerulus:

  • The glomerulus is a network of capillaries located at the beginning of a nephron in the kidney.
  • Histologically, it appears as a round, densely cellular structure surrounded by a Bowman's capsule.
  • It contains capillary loops, mesangial cells, and podocytes.
  • The structure in the image shows tightly packed cells and capillaries, characteristic of a renal glomerulus.

Reference:

Histology, Nephron - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: The anomaly demonstrated in the image is due to a developmental defect in which of the following pharyngeal arch arteries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The condition shown in the image is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus (a fetal blood vessel connecting the pulmonary artery to the aorta) fails to close after birth.

  • The ductus arteriosus is derived from the left 6th pharyngeal arch artery.

questions.text: Which of the following adult structures arises from the embryonic structure indicated in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure is the allantois, a hindgut diverticulum. It forms the urachus during fetal development, connecting the bladder apex to the umbilicus, which later degenerates into the median umbilical ligament. This ligament runs along the midline of the abdominal wall.


Meckel's diverticulum (Option C): This arises from the vitelline duct, not the urachus.

Reference:

Urachal remnant causing umbilical in-drawing during micturition - PMC

choices.text: Left colic vein and middle colic vein
Oesophageal veins and left gastric veins

questions.text: A patient with a known history of liver cirrhosis presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and signs of portal hypertension. Which of the following venous anastomoses is most likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has portal hypertension, which is commonly associated with liver cirrhosis.

  • Portal hypertension leads to the development of portosystemic anastomoses, which are connections between the portal vein and systemic venous circulation.
  • One significant site of such an anastomosis is between the oesophageal veins (draining into the systemic circulation via the azygos vein) and the left gastric vein (draining into the portal vein).
  • In portal hypertension, increased pressure in the portal vein causes blood to flow through these collateral veins, leading to oesophageal varices.

Portal Hypertension: Reversal of blood flow away from the portal vein due to high pressure.

Clinical Features:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Esophageal varices
  • Rectal varices
  • Caput medusae

Explanation for other options:

Left colic vein and middle colic veins (Option A): These veins are part of the portal circulation and do not form portosystemic anastomoses.

Superior and phrenic veins (Option C): These are systemic veins and do not involve the portal system.

Sigmoid and superior rectal veins (Option D): both are part of the portal circulation but don't drain into the systemic circulation; thus, anastomoses between them aren't seen in portal hypertension.

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient reports pain and swelling just below the left ear. Inflammation or involvement of which of the following anatomical structures is the most probable cause of the discomfort?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The greater auricular nerve, originating from the cervical plexus, innervates the skin around the ear, angle of the mandible, and parotid region.

  • It runs superficially along the neck and over the sternocleidomastoid muscle, making it prone to injury or irritation, leading to pain and swelling.
  • Pain and swelling under the left ear lobule could indicate involvement of this nerve, possibly due to inflammation or compression.

The External Ear consists of two main parts:

  • Pinna (Auricle)
  • External Auditory Meatus
